headline: Punch Police Department ($PunchPol) Crashes 94% â€” Another PUNCH Derivative Burns Through $1.7M in Volume
subheadline: The baby monkey cinematic universe expands to pump.fun. The chart says everything you need to know.
author: MemeDesk Editorial

tokenData.name: Punch Police Department
tokenData.recentAction: Pumped to ~$550K mcap within hours of launch, then collapsed 94% to $33K. Volume hit $1.7M before evaporating to $6.9K.

body.text: Every successful meme coin spawns a graveyard of derivatives. PUNCH â€” the Solana-based token inspired by a viral baby macaque that surged 80,000% and hit a $39M market cap â€” just got its first spin-off. Meet Punch Police Department ($PunchPol), a pump.fun graduate that dressed the monkey in a cop uniform, attracted $1.7M in trading volume, and is now sitting at a $33K market cap with a 94% drawdown from its intraday high. The entire lifecycle took roughly two hours.

bullets: $PunchPol launched on pump.fun, graduated to Raydium, pumped to ~$550K mcap, then crashed 94% to $33K â€” all within hours
$1.7M in volume churned through a token that now has 6 transactions and 6 buyers with zero sellers (because there's nothing left to sell)
This is a textbook derivative play riding the PUNCH baby monkey narrative â€” no original concept, no team, no community beyond a dead X community link

body.text: Honestly? Nothing. That's the story. $PunchPol is a pump.fun token that took the PUNCH baby macaque meme â€” which itself went viral after a Japanese zoo rescued an abandoned monkey â€” and slapped a police uniform on it. The token description reads like AI-generated filler: 'Punch the monkey dressed as a police officer carefully places handcuffs on a plush companion, blending playful imagination with a touch of dramatic storytelling.' The only dramatic storytelling here is the chart.

The original PUNCH token surged 80,000% from launch, got listed on a major CEX, and built genuine community momentum around the rescued macaque narrative. $PunchPol tried to draft behind that energy with a pump.fun launch and an X community page that leads nowhere meaningful. It graduated from the bonding curve â€” meaning it hit the liquidity threshold to migrate to Raydium â€” but graduation doesn't mean survival. It means enough early buyers pushed it through the gate before the exit door opened.

At time of writing, $PunchPol sits at $0.043 per token with a market cap of $33,000. Let that number sink in â€” thirty-three thousand dollars. The token churned $1.7M in volume on its way up and back down, which means the vast majority of that volume was early snipers rotating in and out while retail held bags. Current on-chain activity shows 6 total transactions, 6 buyers, zero sellers, and $6.9K in remaining volume. The buy-to-sell ratio looks bullish on paper until you realize there's simply no one left to sell to.

flags: 94% crash from intraday high within hours of launch â€” classic pump.fun dump pattern
No identifiable team, no website, no whitepaper â€” just a pump.fun token with a picture
X community link leads to a freshly created community with no real engagement
Derivative of PUNCH with zero original concept â€” riding coattails of an existing viral narrative
Volume collapsed from $1.7M to $6.9K â€” liquidity has effectively evaporated
Only 6 unique buyers remaining on-chain â€” this token is functionally dead

body.text: Nobody notable. No KOL calls. No smart money wallets. No CT engagement. The $1.7M in volume came from the standard pump.fun playbook: bot snipers, copy-traders monitoring new launches, and a handful of manual apes who saw 'Punch' in the name and clicked buy. The token's X community has no verified accounts, no engagement history, and no evidence of coordinated promotion beyond the launch itself.

This is a pattern worth understanding even if this specific token isn't worth trading. When a meme coin goes viral â€” like PUNCH did with its 80,000% run â€” pump.fun becomes a factory for derivatives. PunchPol, PunchCat, PunchDog, PunchWhatever. Each one launches with a slight twist on the original meme, catches a few hundred thousand in volume from traders scanning for the 'next PUNCH,' and dies within hours. The original PUNCH succeeded because it had a genuine viral catalyst (a rescued baby monkey that captured mainstream attention). Derivatives have none of that. They're photocopies of photocopies.

The lesson for degens scanning DexScreener's new pairs: high volume on a derivative doesn't mean adoption. It means churn. When you see $1.7M volume on a 2-hour-old token that's already down 94%, you're not looking at opportunity. You're looking at the aftermath.

ðŸ”´ Shill Alert. $PunchPol is a dead derivative with no community, no catalyst, and no reason to exist beyond pump.fun's infinite token factory. The $1.7M in volume was entrance and exit liquidity for snipers â€” not a sign of genuine interest. If you're looking for PUNCH exposure, the original token is still trading with actual market cap and community behind it. This one belongs in the forensics drawer.

items.question: What is Punch Police Department ($PunchPol)?
items.answer: PunchPol is a pump.fun-launched Solana meme token themed around the viral PUNCH baby macaque meme, depicting the monkey in a police uniform. It launched, graduated from the bonding curve, hit $1.7M in volume, and crashed 94% within hours.

items.question: Is $PunchPol related to the original PUNCH token?
items.answer: No. PunchPol is an unofficial derivative â€” a separate token launched by unknown creators on pump.fun that uses the PUNCH monkey imagery. It has no connection to the original PUNCH team or community.

items.question: Should I buy $PunchPol at these prices?
items.answer: The token has a $33K market cap, 6 buyers, and virtually zero liquidity. Even if you wanted to speculate on a bounce, there may not be enough liquidity to enter or exit a position. The chart and on-chain data suggest this token's lifecycle is complete.

items.question: Why did $PunchPol pump to $1.7M in volume?
items.answer: Pump.fun tokens with recognizable names (especially derivatives of trending tokens) attract automated snipers and copy-traders who scan new launches. The volume represents rapid rotation by these actors, not organic community buying.
